Back row left to right: Cynnamon Hawkins and DonevaVest-Brown. Front row left to right: Lizzy Hawkins, Abby Hawkins,Melody Nilson, Baily Gimlin, and Nahaleigh Schuster.JIM FISHERFOR THE SENTINELMonday night’s city councilmeeting was brief butbusy, with the session opento the public lasting barely20 minutes. The main pointsof focus were in regard tothe city fire department’slong standing need for a newfirefighting brush truck andthe final phases of completionfor the ongoing BrooksStreet construction project.Council Member Guy Theriaultand Police Chief RickJohnson were absent.After agenda approvalswere made, Public Works DirectorKarl Enyeart madehis department report to thecouncil. He briefly discussedprogress on the pavementoverlay soon to take place inthe shaved-down section ofColumbus Street, where itconnects with Brooks.Paving work there isplanned to be done by nextweek. He then went over thecurrent situation with thewatershed surplus timberproposal, stating that severallogging companies answeringthe city’s call for bid proposalshad gone on site visitsto the watershed property,showing interest in makinga bid, but none had yet submittedone officially. Modificationsare currently beingmade to the city’s proposalpaperwork, with some refinementsto what is mostlyscheduling criteria. Finalproposals from the loggingoutfits are expected to besubmitted by Sept. 4 for reviewby the city.Next, City AdministratorLarry Bellamy took the floorto discuss the finishingtouches to the ObservatorySee City, Page 2Family, 4-H, and a candoattitude help adream come trueDALLAS SMITHREPORTER“When you have a childborn with Down syndrome,doctors tell you all the thingsthey can’t do,” says DianeNilson, mother of Melodyand Mariah Nilson. Herdaughter Melody was bornwith Down syndrome andhas all of the difficulties thatcome with it, but she saysthat’s just what they are—difficulties.Rather than beingintimidated, they workedthat much harder to achievetheir goals, and Melody’s goalis to show her horse at theKlickitat County Fair.Melody is proof that no challengeis insurmountable.Melody’s older sister Mariahwas the Klickitat CountyFair and Rodeo Queen lastyear. Like many younger siblings,Melody wanted to belike her sister; showing herhorse at the fair. Last yearMelody and Diane weren’tquite prepared, but this yearwith the help of their 4-Hgroup, the Mount AdamsCommunity 4-H Club HorseDivision, they’re ready toroll. No member of the grouphas ever shown at the fair before,though two of the horseshad appeared. Melody’shorse, Scout, is one of the experiencedhorses because hewas Mariah’s queeninghorse, and Mariah decidednot to show this year so thatMelody could use Scout.Melody practices two toANDREW CHRISTIANSENREPORTERIt is rare to have a robberyin Goldendale, but last weekwas an exception with therobbery and motor vehicletheft that took place in theparking lot of McDonalds’restaurant. The suspect,Donovan Cloud was apprehendedtwo days later byYakama Nation Tribal Policeand will be charged in KlickitatCounty.The incident happened onAug. 13, around 8:30 p.m. Accordingto the Goldendale Policereport, Klickitat Countydispatch reported a man hadjust robbed another man atknife point at McDonalds andstole his pick-up. He was reportedlyheaded south onSR97.“Within 30 seconds, wehad seven officers (includingSheriff’s deputies and StatePatrol) responding, cuttingoff roads to the south,” saidLt. Reggie Bartkowski.“When our officer arrived atthe scene and interviewedwitnesses, we discovered hethree times a week either atthe Glenwood arena or athome. Because Melody’s confidencetends to vary fromday to day, sometimes theywill get in a five-minute ride,sometimes an hour. “Melodyis very visual so we tried todo as much visually as possible,and I had to slow downand break it down for Mel,”says Doneva Vest-Brown, the4-H group’s leader. To makethings more visual, they’duse cones or markers to helpMelody. Seeing a visual representationhelped her to focus.The girls in the grouphelped Melody become amore confident rider. Theyencouraged her to do the exercisesand were patient,slowing down to help her.“Melody is such a fun, kind,loving, and sincere person.Having Mel involved for meand my kids is so wonderful.When she sees a need, shefills it,” says CynnamonHawkins, the assistant leaderof the group.Everyone in the 4-H grouphas worked to help Melodyand Diane overcome the challengesthat they have facedon their way to being preparedfor the fair this year.The help from each and everyperson has been invaluablein helping Melody and Dianeachieve their goals in beingable to participate in the fair.They turned their can’ts intocans as they made their waytowards this goal.Vehicle stolen fromMcDonalds’ parking lothad actually headed north.”Lt. Bartkowski says the originalcall to the dispatcher hadthe information correct. Subsequentcalls led to the wrongdirection being sent out bythe dispatcher. It was enoughof a head-start to allow thethief to escape.Police learned that a mandescribed as an adult NativeAmerican was in McDonaldsand had told a witness that hehad recently been releasedfrom prison. Witnesses saidthe man was in the parkinglot asking people for a ride. Averbal altercation occurredbetween the man and theowner of a white, 1993 Nissanpick-up. The suspect orderedthe man out of the pick-up atknife point. He complied andwas unharmed.The Goldendale Police Departmentcontacted the Departmentof Corrections(DOC) and local jails to seewho might have been recentlyreleased. Given that therewas no specific date to workwith nor which state mayhave released him, it was ashot in the dark to find a suspect.On Aug. 14, Yakama NationTribal Police pursuedthe stolen pick-up. TheGorge Winds performed a summery bill of variousmarches and some Broadway tunes.WWIIreenactmentgroupcomes toGoldendaleJIM FISHERFOR THE SENTINELTime rolled backwards by69 years a few weekends agoin the area surrounding asprawling hilltop not farfrom the Klickitat River. Forthree days the usually quietvalleys echoed with thesounds of heavy gunfire as aunit of the Red Army and aragged band of partisansmet soldiers of the ThirdReich in battle. Despite theferocity of the combatants,the casualty list remainedextremely short; mostly blistersand bruises, due largelyto the fact that blanks werethe only shots fired and allwere in simulated anger.History enthusiasts froma group called RKKA Northwestrepresented the RussianArmy at a weekend-longcombat reenactment eventheld Aug. 9-11, on propertyowned by the HorseshoeBend Ranch west of Centerville.The RKKA, whose initialstranslated into Englishmean “Workers and PeasantsRed Army,” is a subdivisionof the larger ArmyGroup 1944 organization(AG44), which includes representationsof the British,CONTRIBUTED: KAREN BELANGERRUSSIANS IN WASHINGTON: Patrick Ireland, left, and “Russian commander” JasonSloate advance on German forces during a World War II reenactment near Goldendale.American, German, Soviet,and Resistance fighters fromvarious European countries,all based in the PacificNorthwest. This most recentevent was themed aroundbattles that took place in theCrimean area near the BlackSea in war-torn eastern Europe,1944. The group hasbeen holding events at theranch since 2010 and has amutually beneficial relationshipwith the property owners,according to event organizers.The area available forhistorical reenactmentgroups is proudly advertisedon the Horseshoe BendRanch website. Members ofAG44 also stage a large yearlyD-Day reenactment inJune on ranch grounds.Authenticity is king atAG44 events, from the riflesin their hands to the kitswith which they camp. Unlikemany public displayreenactments, most of theAG44 battles are viewable byparticipants only.
